episodes.title: Capitalism Isn't a Dirty Word
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.948
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.006 --> 00:00:14.744
Capitalism has been at the center
of economic prosperity and

3
00:00:14.744 --> 00:00:16.940
freedom for centuries.

4
00:00:16.940 --> 00:00:21.470
But when you hear names like Bernie Madoff
or hear about the shenanigans of companies

5
00:00:21.470 --> 00:00:26.000
like Enron, well,
capitalism can become a dirty word.

6
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:29.200
Hello, I'm Eric Wright
along with Jeff Piersall.

7
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:33.480
And we're here today with TREP talks
to talk about some of the questions

8
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:35.620
entrepreneurs are asking.

9
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:42.250
And the question we're delving into
today is, capitalism isn't a dirty word.

10
00:00:42.250 --> 00:00:46.100
Jeff, have greed and
capitalism become, well,

11
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:49.120
synonymous?
>> It's a great question, Eric,

12
00:00:49.120 --> 00:00:54.020
and what has really happened
over the course of time is that

13
00:00:54.020 --> 00:00:58.870
capitalism has created so
much temptation for people.

14
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:04.140
And when left unchecked, that temptation
will lend itself to greed and

15
00:01:04.140 --> 00:01:06.980
those opportunities of selfishness when

16
00:01:06.980 --> 00:01:11.570
actually capitalism is supposed to
be designed for that one thing and

17
00:01:11.570 --> 00:01:16.670
that one opportunity to really drive
the opportunity of freedom for all people.

18
00:01:16.670 --> 00:01:21.550
And it's what made our country great, but
today, it is very confused by itself in

19
00:01:21.550 --> 00:01:25.480
its own definition.
>> Jeff, it's almost like if we're not

20
00:01:25.480 --> 00:01:30.330
governed by some sort of internal compass,
we're going to be forced to

21
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:35.000
be governed by something on
the outside that nobody really wants.

22
00:01:35.000 --> 00:01:38.380
So we coin this term ethical capitalism.

23
00:01:38.380 --> 00:01:40.920
Why don't you unpack that for us, Jeff?

24
00:01:40.920 --> 00:01:44.940
And how does it sort of address
this problem that we're discussing?

25
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:47.350
>> Yeah, Eric, ethical capitalism,

26
00:01:47.350 --> 00:01:54.120
by definition, creates a method, in a way,
in which capitalism can prosper.

27
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:58.270
Ethical meaning, let's just do
the right thing at the right time, and

28
00:01:58.270 --> 00:01:59.880
at the right place.

29
00:01:59.880 --> 00:02:04.880
And capitalism being the difference
between the private sector driving profit,

30
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:08.950
or the public sector driving profit,
in reality,

31
00:02:08.950 --> 00:02:11.240
you don't want the public
sector driving private.

32
00:02:11.240 --> 00:02:14.020
We already know what the end
conclusion to that is.

33
00:02:14.020 --> 00:02:14.520
>> Yes,

34
00:02:14.520 --> 00:02:17.910
yes, gross inefficiency in most cases.

35
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:18.590
Now and

36
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:24.280
essential to this whole principle of
ethical capitalism is the idea of freedom.

37
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:28.700
And so let's talk about freedom and let's
talk about the elements of freedom that

38
00:02:28.700 --> 00:02:31.480
impact each and every one of us.
>> Yeah,

39
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:34.920
when you think about ethical capitalism,
you gotta go back and

40
00:02:34.920 --> 00:02:39.280
get to the root fundamental of what
really drives all human beings.

41
00:02:39.280 --> 00:02:41.970
And it really doesn't matter if
we're talking about terrorists, or

42
00:02:41.970 --> 00:02:44.290
we're talking about business owners,-
>> Everybody.

43
00:02:44.290 --> 00:02:45.850
>> Or we're talking a single mom at home.

44
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:47.260
It's everybody.

45
00:02:47.260 --> 00:02:53.540
We're wired for freedom from birth of
all cultures, all genders, all sexes.

46
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:58.870
And there's four components
that really drive that which is

47
00:02:58.870 --> 00:03:03.410
freedom of time, freedom of money,
freedom of relationships,

48
00:03:03.410 --> 00:03:06.010
and freedom of purpose.
>> Okay, and

49
00:03:06.010 --> 00:03:10.060
Jeff, I know that these things didn't come
out of something that you read in a book.

50
00:03:10.060 --> 00:03:15.130
This idea of freedom came out of your own
personal experience as an entrepreneur.

51
00:03:15.130 --> 00:03:18.520
And so, maybe share a little
bit of that journey with us,

52
00:03:18.520 --> 00:03:21.510
how this idea of freedom captured you and

53
00:03:21.510 --> 00:03:26.560
began to drive you as an entrepreneur.
>> Yeah, Eric, it really starts back in

54
00:03:26.560 --> 00:03:31.690
a summer around July 7th or
8th for me, when I was working for

55
00:03:31.690 --> 00:03:35.420
a gentleman, making more money than
I had ever made in my history.

56
00:03:35.420 --> 00:03:38.400
And this was about 15 years ago.

57
00:03:38.400 --> 00:03:43.650
And my daughter was between her junior and
senior year, was in a head-on crash, and

58
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:48.630
she was airlifted to the hospital,
was there all night and

59
00:03:48.630 --> 00:03:52.020
great thing, there was no alcohol or
anything like that involved.

60
00:03:52.020 --> 00:03:54.470
It was just the other driver fell asleep.

61
00:03:54.470 --> 00:03:58.800
And we get to the hospital,
we finally get through the surgeries.

62
00:03:58.800 --> 00:04:02.370
I get on the phone with my
boss the next morning and

63
00:04:02.370 --> 00:04:06.500
it's about 7 AM and
I go through this whole scenario.

64
00:04:06.500 --> 00:04:11.340
And he ends the conversation with okay,
Jeff, great, I guess I'll see you in

65
00:04:11.340 --> 00:04:13.917
an hour at the office.
>> You've got to be kidding me.

66
00:04:13.917 --> 00:04:17.224
[LAUGH]
>> And everything in me turned upside

67
00:04:17.224 --> 00:04:18.510
down.
>> Yeah.

68
00:04:18.510 --> 00:04:23.200
And it was at that point it
became the passion to drive for

69
00:04:23.200 --> 00:04:27.190
that time freedom and for
those relationship freedoms.

70
00:04:27.190 --> 00:04:34.380
And later it became the financial freedoms
which we'll talk about in other courses.

71
00:04:34.380 --> 00:04:37.290
And then of course the purpose
freedom which I think, so for

72
00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:40.940
me personally it was all about
the time and the relationship and

73
00:04:40.940 --> 00:04:46.470
it was driven by an event which can happen
to any of us where it creates the trigger.

74
00:04:46.470 --> 00:04:50.060
It took me eight to nine
months to break out of

75
00:04:51.375 --> 00:04:54.135
confines of that relationship.
>> But boy,

76
00:04:54.135 --> 00:04:58.241
it's led to the last 14 years of great
time freedom and relationship freedom.

77
00:04:58.241 --> 00:05:01.305
>> Wow, the main principles of ethical

78
00:05:01.305 --> 00:05:05.965
capitalism are discussed in our book,
Dogs Don't Bark at Parked Cars.

79
00:05:05.965 --> 00:05:07.975
And as I was listening to you Jeff,

80
00:05:07.975 --> 00:05:12.910
I was thinking about two really key
elements that you have discussed

81
00:05:12.910 --> 00:05:17.010
with me many times that are essential
to this concept to freedom.

82
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:21.680
Why don't you break those down for a sec?
>> [LAUGH] You can have all the drive and

83
00:05:21.680 --> 00:05:26.630
purpose that you want and you could
have all the desire for time, money,

84
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:31.190
relationships, and purpose,
but at the end of the day,

85
00:05:31.190 --> 00:05:36.060
if you don't have faith and
the courage to actually pursue it,

86
00:05:36.060 --> 00:05:38.355
you're gonna end up missing it.
>> Right.

87
00:05:38.355 --> 00:05:40.990
>> I always talk about the guy who sits

88
00:05:40.990 --> 00:05:43.190
on the couch and he's got all the desire,

89
00:05:43.190 --> 00:05:47.220
he's got all the reasons, he's got all
the knowledge, but at the end of the day,

90
00:05:47.220 --> 00:05:50.340
he doesn't have the courage
to get off the couch and go.

91
00:05:50.340 --> 00:05:52.572
And then you just gotta
have the faith in yourself.

92
00:05:52.572 --> 00:05:56.630
You gotta have the faith and
the belief that your courage and

93
00:05:56.630 --> 00:06:01.230
those things that are important to
you are worth it and you deserve it.

94
00:06:01.230 --> 00:06:06.730
Too many people spend to much time in
a process of actually battling against

95
00:06:06.730 --> 00:06:10.590
themselves, than ever giving themselves
the chance by just having the faith for

96
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:13.780
the future.
>> Right, right, that's so good, Jeff.

97
00:06:13.780 --> 00:06:19.940
Now, what can the viewers that
are watching here today do to help

98
00:06:19.940 --> 00:06:24.515
incorporate these principles of freedom
and ethical capitalism into their life?

99
00:06:24.515 --> 00:06:28.680
Now one of them, Jeff and I wrote a book
called, Dogs Don't Park at Parked Cars.

100
00:06:28.680 --> 00:06:31.760
It's available at Amazon,
you can pick it up at your bookstore.

101
00:06:31.760 --> 00:06:34.550
And we worked through in detail
some of these principles.

102
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:38.670
But Jeff, help our viewers have some
takeaways on how they can incorporate

103
00:06:38.670 --> 00:06:41.730
ethical capitalism,
particularly freedom into their own life.

104
00:06:41.730 --> 00:06:44.619
>> Yeah, I think very most importantly is

105
00:06:44.619 --> 00:06:49.783
to understand, this sounds so easy,
it's just do the right thing and

106
00:06:49.783 --> 00:06:54.175
let's drive this through
the private sector with profit.

107
00:06:54.175 --> 00:06:59.653
But when you get down to the real final,
nut and grind of this whole thing Eric,

108
00:06:59.653 --> 00:07:04.882
these decisions become very difficult and
the decisions you're making,

109
00:07:04.882 --> 00:07:10.446
somebody's always typically going to come
out on the shorter end of the stick.

110
00:07:10.446 --> 00:07:15.230
And so, people will look at you and go,
you're unethical because that hurt me.

111
00:07:15.230 --> 00:07:18.491
Well actually, what it did is it probably
freed you up to go do what you're supposed

112
00:07:18.491 --> 00:07:21.300
to be doing.
>> Forced you to do what you need to do.

113
00:07:21.300 --> 00:07:22.520
>> And that really starts

114
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:26.890
the conversation, which is the first
thing that everybody needs to do is

115
00:07:26.890 --> 00:07:31.770
define what freedom is for them in time,

116
00:07:31.770 --> 00:07:34.130
money, relationship, and purpose.
>> Got you.

117
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:35.510
>> Because if you don't write that

118
00:07:35.510 --> 00:07:40.410
down and define it, then you've got no
idea and you're kinda just being pushed

119
00:07:40.410 --> 00:07:44.910
by the wind, and you've really gotta
have a real clear track of that.

120
00:07:44.910 --> 00:07:46.960
And then you've gotta decide,

121
00:07:46.960 --> 00:07:51.940
what price are you willing to
pay to go achieve that freedom?

122
00:07:51.940 --> 00:07:55.670
And there's a lot of people that
really say they want something but

123
00:07:55.670 --> 00:07:57.430
they're not willing to put the effort and

124
00:07:57.430 --> 00:08:00.890
the desire toward achieving it.
>> Jeff,

125
00:08:00.890 --> 00:08:07.220
we have a statement that we often
use that unethical is unsustainable.

126
00:08:07.220 --> 00:08:12.170
That if you operate in an unethical way,
eventually that is going to catch up

127
00:08:12.170 --> 00:08:15.670
to you, eventually it's gonna torpedo
everything you're trying to do and

128
00:08:15.670 --> 00:08:16.770
everything you're trying to get.
>> And

129
00:08:16.770 --> 00:08:17.900
we've got tons of examples.
>> Yeah,

130
00:08:17.900 --> 00:08:21.110
we could spend the rest of
the day unpacking all of those.

131
00:08:21.110 --> 00:08:25.630
But by incorporating these
solutions into your life,

132
00:08:25.630 --> 00:08:28.260
you're going to begin to gain freedom.

133
00:08:28.260 --> 00:08:32.990
And hopefully you're going to arrive at
a place where you're driving your business

134
00:08:32.990 --> 00:08:37.770
instead of your business driving you which
is really the essence of freedom for

135
00:08:37.770 --> 00:08:38.660
an entrepreneur.

136
00:08:38.660 --> 00:08:44.290
And again, we'll talk about that more is
some of our future FREP talk, TREP talks.

137
00:08:44.290 --> 00:08:48.410
So take the time, stop, don't wait,

138
00:08:48.410 --> 00:08:53.900
write down what freedom means to you in
these four terms that Jeff mentioned.

139
00:08:53.900 --> 00:08:54.960
Do it now.

140
00:08:54.960 --> 00:08:59.450
Also, you can go to our website,
TrepBiz.com.

141
00:08:59.450 --> 00:09:02.860
There you can get videos like this,
you can get articles that Jeff and

142
00:09:02.860 --> 00:09:05.430
I have written so that you have help and

143
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:08.170
assistance on your
entrepreneurial journey.

144
00:09:08.170 --> 00:09:10.870
I wanna again thank you for
joining us for TrepTalks.

145
00:09:10.870 --> 00:09:14.110
For myself Eric Wright and
my partner here Jeff Pearsol,

146
00:09:14.110 --> 00:09:18.444
we look forward to continuing this
discussion and further conversations.

147
00:09:18.444 --> 00:09:22.890
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Can I Please Talk to a Person
The Art of Thinking Independently Together
Our Way is Better Than My Way or Your Way
